results.title: Creating a dance (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The first part of the film traces stages in the creation of a demonstration of dance movement, examining the constituent parts and illustrating how the solutions to some of the associated problems were evolved. The second part presents the entire demonstration without comment. Dance direction and narration by Valerie Preston-Dunlop.

results.title: Crayfish for Julie
results.brief_description: Depicts a day in the life of a fisherman catching crayfish off the coast near Fremantle, Western Australia. Briefly traces the growth and development of the crayfish industry. Made with the co operation of the Department of Fisheries Western Australia. Narrated by Clive Winmill.

results.title: Coventry Cathedral construction and consecration
results.brief_description: The building, embellishment and consecration of the new Cathedral Church of St. Michael at Coventry, from the preliminary earth moving in 1955 to completion seven years later, finishing with a tour of the completed cathedral, and the Consecration Ceremony attended by Her Majesty the Queen. Illuminates the contrasting skills which contributed to this achievement, and pays tribute to the architects, builders, engineers, artists and craftsmen who worked in stone and wood, glass, metal and tapestry.

results.title: Coventry and Ottobeuren join hands
results.creator_credit: F I B Dr W Lutje
results.brief_description: In 1964 the Benedictine monastery of Ottobeuren in Bavaria, celebrated its 12th centenary. Taking part in the celebrations was Princess Marina, Duchess of Kent, a manifestation of the cultural ties between Great Britain and Germany.

results.title: Court of Petty Sessions
results.brief_description: A dramatised production examining a typical case at a Police Court in Perth - in this instance a car theft. The defendant pleads not guilty so a preliminary trial must be conducted. The testimony of the plaintiff and the defendant is presented and the importance if the subpoena is noted when one witness fails to attend.

results.title: Country Craft
results.brief_description: For many centuries much of India’s trade has been carried out by the country craft, the sailing vessels which carry produce along the 3,000 miles of India’s coastline. They carry the products of the interior and the south to the east of Calcutta, Rangoon, and Indonesia. They travel to the west to Bombay and Karachi, and across the Arabian Sea and the Indian Ocean, loaded with the coffee copra, coir, rope and textiles, the products of their ports of call.

results.title: Country children
results.creator_credit: Chris Pettit and Churches Television and Radio Centre
results.brief_description: A look at two young boys, aged about two and four, who are growing up on a farm that is run by their parents. The parents discuss the advantages of growing up in the country. They also talk about the problem of the boys being isolated from children their own age and how they overcome it by sending them to a regular playschool.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Pettit and Churches Television and Radio Centre

results.brief_description: A public relations film designed to teach people in public service who deal with the general public that they can maintain the goodwill of a customer even when they must stick to “company policy”.

results.title: Cosmic zoom
results.brief_description:
From the top of the Empire State Building to the edge of the known universe, this breath-taking three-minute video animation sequence was produced for a television documentary series. Using spatial data over a huge range of scales, the sequence was produced using six different renderers, developed specially to deal with planetary surfaces, atmospheres, stars, individual galaxies and groups of galaxies. Aerial photography was combined with high-resolution and global satellite imagery of the Earth. Planetary imagemaps of the Moon, Mars and Saturn were developed from the Clementine, Viking and Voyager missions. The rings of Saturn were derived from Voyager’s occultation experiment and Voyager itself is depicted as a 3D model heading up out of the plane of the solar system. The nearest stars are portrayed with their correct relative positions, magnitude and colour, extracted from astronomical catalogues.

The only object not based directly on scientific observations is our own Milky Way galaxy, half of which is obscured from view from Earth by the dense galactic nucleus. Our galaxy and the neighbouring Andromeda galaxy were rendered using specially-written software which models the 3D distribution of tens of millions of individual stars and clouds of light-blocking dust, using telescopic images as a template. These and the other galaxies were portrayed in their correct relative positions, size, morphological type and dominant colour. By the end of the sequence we are looking back, across chains and walls of galaxies, from the edge of the known universe.
